titleStmt.title: Priests! Until you can explain a paving stone
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive.

notesStmt.note: Thematically and in the wording of one of the lines this manuscript resembles a portion of the second poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, a poem eventually entitled "A Song for Occupations." This connection suggests that this manuscript was composed before or early in 1855.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Priests! Until you can explain a paving stone
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from The Walt Whitman Archive I: Whitman Manuscripts at the Library of Congress, ed. Joel Myerson (New York: Garland, 1993); Major American Authors on CD-Rom: Walt Whitman (Westport, CT: Primary Source Media, 1997). The transcription was then checked against digital images of the original.
On the back is a proposition for a poem "embodying the sentiment of perfect happiness."

revisionDesc.change: created new file for verso, added relatedItem encoding, date note from EAD

work.p: The general theme of this manuscript, as well as the specific wording of one of the lines, resembles a portion of the second poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, a poem eventually entitled "A Song for Occupations." Specifically, it seems to relate to the poem's final stanza, in which Whitman looks forward to a time "[w]hen the sacred vessels or the bits of the eucharist, or the lath and plast, procreate as effectually as the young silvermiths or bakers, or the masons in their overalls." In the manuscript, Whitman likewise criticizes what he perceives to be the lifelessness of organized religion, commanding priests that "[u]ntil your creeds can do as much as apples and hen's eggs . . . And until your brick and mortar can procreate as I can, / I beg you, Sirs, do not presume to put them above me."

lg.l:
Priests! Until you can explain a paving stone, to every ones my perfect satisfaction O Priests, do
not try to explain God:

add.l: Until your creeds can do as much as apples and hen's eggs, restrain pull let down your eyebrows a little,

lg.l:
¶ Until your Bibles and prayer-books are able to
walk like me,

And until your brick and mortar can procreate
as I can,

I beg you, sSirs, do not presume to put them
above me.
